Award.AwardTitle: Conformational Dynamics Associated with Ca2+ Binding to DREAM Protein

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Downstream Regulatory Element Antagonist Modulator (DREAM), also known as calsenilin or K+ channel interacting protein 3 (KChIP-3) belongs to the group of neuronal calcium sensor proteins that are found predominantly in neuronal cells where they regulate diverse aspects of neuronal function ranging from neurotransmitter release to neuronal growth and apoptosis. DREAM is a highly multifunctional protein that interacts with presenilin-1 and presenilin-2, acts as a transcriptional repressor for a number of genes including c-fos gene and prodynorphin gene in Ca2+ dependent manner, and interacts and modulates the activity of A-type of K+ channels. Understanding how calcium-induced conformational changes within EF-hand motifs of DREAM control the protein association to DNA target sequence and modulate the K+ channel activity requires determination of kinetics and energetics of conformational changes that are associated with the transition between apo- and calcium-loaded forms of DREAM as well characterization the impact of the Ca2+ binding on the DREAM equilibrium dynamics. The emphasis of this project is to probe conformational heterogeneity and dynamic motion of DREAM in apo- and Ca2+ bound state using time-resolved fluorescence and anisotropy techniques and to construct time-resolved thermodynamic profiles in terms of volume and enthalpy changes for Ca2+/Mg2+ binding to DREAM using sensitive photothermal beam deflection method in combination with caged calcium compounds that enable rapid increase in Ca2+ concentration. This study will thus determine the role of the individual EF-hands in the Ca2+ signal transductions, the mechanism of signal transduction between the C- and N-terminal domains as well as the role of N- and C-terminal helices in interaction between DREAM and effector proteins.

This project will provide multi-disciplinary educational opportunities to graduate and undergraduate students, who will receive broad training in modern experimental biophysics and biochemical methods including protein chemistry. Students' work will be disseminated at national and regional meetings and students will co-author publications. The emphases will be on giving students hands on exposure to advanced topics in an effort to stimulate their interest in chemistry and biophysics. The effort to recruit and train female and minority students will continue with the goal to increase participation and retention of students that are underrepresented in sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Downstream Regulatory Element Antagonist Modulator (DREAM) is a multi-functional protein that regulates vita neuronal processes such as potassium voltage channels kinetics, pain sensing and calcium homeostasis. Here we have shown that calcium association to DREAM does not trigger larges changes in the overall proteins structure but modifies the protein dynamics as evident from the time resolved fluorescence studies. Calcium triggered alternation of protein dynamics may be a key factor in calcium dependent DREAM interactions with other intra-cellar proteins and DNA. Unlike calcium, magnesium binding to DREAM does not alters DREAM structure or dynamics but increases DREAM stability in the presence of calcium. In the timer resolved anisotropy and calcium binding kinetic studies we have shown that in the absence of calcium, DREAM is in equilibrium between a monomeric and dimer form whereas calcium bond dimer is assembled from DREAM monomers. Using hydrophobic fluorescence probes, we have identified a hydrophobic surface located in the C-terminal domain of DREAM as a binding interface for small hydrophobic molecules including arachidonic acid and NS5806 compound, a recently developed drug that impact gating properties of potassium voltage channels in complex with DREAM. We have also shown that the residues 28-44 located in the dynamically disordered DREAM N-terminus provide a binding site for calmodulin and formation of DREAM-calmoduliin complex inhibits DREAM association to DNA. Interestingly, we have also shown that DREAM binding to potassium voltage channels is calcium dependent suggesting that the structural/dynamic changes associated with calcium binding to the DREAM C-terminus are transmitted to the N-terminal domain either through inter-domain or inter-protein interactions.

 

Broader Impact

Considering DREAM role in Alzheimer disease and in regulation of genes involved in pain sensing, understanding of DREAM interactions with calcium, small hydrophobic molecules and other proteins  provides a molecular bases for new approaches to treat Alzheimer disease and pain management. This project provided a multidisciplinary training environment for high school, undergraduate and graduate students in STEM field including minority students and students participating in the NSF founded REU program.  Upon graduation, student involved in this project successfully continued their professional career in the graduate schools in chemistry and related fields. Importantly, students involved in this project presented their results at local and national meetings.
